title: What are literary devices and what are some examples? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hi. Good question; both terms are usually referred to in tandem and thats why many people aren't clear on what falls into the literary technique category as opposed to a literary device. Because words are inherently paradoxical (they're nothing more than structured symbols organized according to rules of a particular language, yet they are the foundation human communication and harness immense power power (even more so when they're written)), clarying literary devices and techniques is never a simple task. Most authors/writers usually don't have the luxury of being present when their work is read, so they must use words to convey the complex and vast range of situations, emotions, senses, understandings, and states of being that human may experience and/or react to. Literary devices are standard writing mechanics that are used to enhance an idea, thought, or feeling that a writer wishes to express. Unlike oration, where the speaker’s tone of voice and body gestures, or lack thereof, often add (or detract) from the meaning of the words being spoken, authors must rely on literary devices and/or techniques to enhance the written word. The best way to differentiate between literary devices and techniques is to think of anything that is written is a house (structure) that was crafted (built) by a carpenter (author) for a specific purpose (educate, entertain, criticize, etc.). Literary devices are the items that the author chooses to focus on to best suit the purpose of the house. There are only six (6) areas that writers create and/or focus on or else theyre doing something else; not writing… Just as carpenters can only work on constructing certain things else what is created will not look like a house (I.e. kitchen, living room, bathroom, bedrooms, etc). The most universal literary devices are characterization, theme, plot, mood, tone and setting. Writers can use all of the former or just one. Literary techniques, on the other hand, are how the writer chooses to construct the literary device(s). Just like a carpenter might decide to craft a living room that is sunken and contains a spiral staircase, so might an author describe the setting of a character’s hometown using an extended mixed metaphor and an alliteration. Easiest way to remember: devices are what’s being developed and techniques are how the writer is choosing to develop that device. Another way is DEVICE has 6 letters and there are 6 literary devices; TECHNIQUES begins with ‘T’ and they are the specific tools used by authors. How effectively/creatively/purposefully etc. an author chooses the myriad of techniques and device combinations is ultimately separates excellent writers from mediocre ones. My apology for the lengthy reponse, but I wanted to answer your question thoroughly but without all the jargon that can impede clarity.

Simile, metaphor, personifiaction, alliteration, hyperbole, understatement, repetition, allusions, and so on. Metaphors compare to unlike things and can be extended or run through a poem . Her face was the wreckage of the Edmund Fitzgerald Simile is essentially the same thing but it employed the the like to make the connection : My love is like a red red rose. Personification uses human characteristics to describe something that isn't human . The wind cries Mary. Allitreation repeats the same sound at the beginning of a word . She sells sea shells by the sea shore. Hyperbole is simply overstatement . I was hungry I could have eaten a horse. You can look these up on any college or secondary school age site that pertains to English courses under poetry . These questions are part of the tenth grade assessment in ELA for California.
